titlestmt.title: Joseph and Potiphar's Wife: electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the Library of Congress

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 9KB; 6 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 39KB to 1200KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and Archives March 2010
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of 20 of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. These designs illustrate the Old Testament and are arranged according to the passages illustrated. They are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
The Bible had an enormous influence on Blake’s work as both artist and poet. Among his many and complex responses to that text are water color drawings. The present group of 20 is selected from a sequence of about 80 biblical water colors of similar size Blake painted for Thomas Butts between c. 1800 and 1805. These designs emphasize interactions between the human and the divine. In works such as Ezekiel’s Wheels and David Delivered Out of Many Waters , the interaction is revelatory or redemptive. In other designs, including Pestilence: The Death of the First-Born , the relationship between God and humankind devolves into punishment and destruction.
This group of 20 water colors is the first installment in our publication of a large selection of Blake’s water color drawings illustrating the Bible. In coming months we will publish a group of New Testament illustrations also from the series executed for Butts. Later we will add early works, such as Abraham and Isaac , datable to c. 1780, and continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, including Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes of c. 1824.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: Anonymous delineator. The inscriptions on the mount, available under Related Works in the Archive, are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color
objinfo.framelines: The design is surrounded by a single pen and ink framing line, contiguous with the edge of the image, on all four sides.

provenance.name: Yale Center for British Art
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts c. 1803-05; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold Sotheby's, 26 March 1852, lot 156, titled "Joseph and Jezebel" as in the inscription on the mount above the design (£1.2s. to the dealer Henry G. Bohn); the dealer Robson and Co., offered in their catalogue 63 of Aug. 1897, item 85, and in their catalogue 82 of c. 1904, item 47 (£52.10s.); acquired in 1904 by W. Graham Robertson; sold from Robertson's collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 5 (£220.10s. to the Fine Art Society, a dealer); the dealer C. A. Stonehill; Mrs. Hannah D. Rabinowitz by 1950; sold through the dealer Charles Traylen to Paul Mellon in 1974; given by Mellon to the Yale Center for British Art in 1977.

objnote.p: Blake signed the work, lower left, with his monogram.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates Potiphar's wife accusing Joseph of attempted rape, Genesis 39:7-20. In the center of the design stands Potiphar's wife, facing left and slightly forward. Her gown swirls at the hem to indicate rapid movement, striding or walking to the left. She has long hair pulled up in a bun, with a band in her hair. Her legs are bent, with her left leg extended slightly backward and left foot on tiptoe. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she points at Joseph. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees, and in that hand she holds a cloth or garment. Her mouth is open (she is probably speaking) and she looks upward at her husband. To the left of Potiphar's wife stands a man, facing forward and to the left—presumably Potiphar himself. Potiphar has curly hair and a beard. He wears a gown and possibly a long cloak or robe. He stands with his right arm bent and held to his chest and his left arm at his side. His mouth is slightly open. His facial expression suggests surprise. To the left of Potiphar stands Joseph, facing right and slightly forward. He stands, partly clothed in a toga-like gown. His right arm is at his side, palm down. Joseph has short, curly hair and looks at Potiphar's wife with his mouth slightly open. His facial expression suggests surprise. Three female servants observe this scene. The leftmost female stands to the left of Joseph. She has curly hair and wears a gown. The lower half of her body faces left, but she twists to look forward and to the right. Her left leg is bent and on tiptoe, as though she is in mid-stride. Her arms are bent and she balances on her head a wicker basket full of grapes in bunches, with their leaves still attached. The middle female servant stands between Potiphar and his wife. She has curly hair and wears a gown. She faces forward and slightly left, as though looking at Joseph. Her right leg is extended forward, as though she is in mid-stride. The rightmost female servant stands to the right of Potiphar's wife. She has curly hair and wears a gown. She faces forward and left, as if looking at Joseph. Her right arm is at her side, palm down. This scene takes place in a well-lit room, judging from the shadows visible on the floor. In the background a wall is visible through an open doorway. Two pyramids are visible through the doorway. The sky, as seen through the doorway, has a few clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design stands Potiphar's wife, facing left and slightly forward. Her gown swirls at the hem to indicate rapid movement, striding or walking to the left. She has long hair pulled up in a bun, with a band in her hair. Her legs are bent, with her left leg extended slightly backward and on tiptoe. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she points at Joseph. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees, and in that hand she holds a cloth or garment. Her mouth is open (she is probably speaking) and she looks upward at her husband.

To the left of Potiphar's wife stands a man, facing forward and to the left—presumably Potiphar himself. Potiphar has curly hair and a beard. He wears a gown and possibly a long cloak or robe. He stands with his right arm bent and held to his chest and his left arm at his side. His mouth is slightly open. His facial expression suggests surprise.

To the left of Potiphar stands Joseph, facing right and slightly forward. He stands, partly clothed in a toga-like gown. His right arm is at his side, palm down. Joseph has short, curly hair and looks at Potiphar's wife with his mouth slightly open. His facial expression suggests surprise.

Three female servants observe this scene. The leftmost female stands to the left of Joseph. She has curly hair and wears a gown. The lower half of her body faces left, but she twists to look forward and to the right. Her left leg is bent and on tiptoe, as though she is mid-stride. Her arms are bent and she balances a basket on her head.

Three female servants observe this scene. The middle female servant stands between Potiphar and his wife. She has curly hair and wears a gown. She faces forward and slightly left, as though looking at Joseph. Her right leg is extended forward, as though she is in mid-stride.

Three female servants observe this scene. The rightmost female servant stands to the right of Potiphar's wife. She has curly hair and wears a gown. She faces forward and left, as if looking at Joseph. Her right arm is at her side, palm down.
The leftmost female servant balances on her head a wicker basket full of grapes in bunches, with their leaves still attached.
This scene takes place in a well-lit room, judging from the shadows visible on the floor.
Objects in the background are visible through an open doorway.
In the background a wall is visible through an open doorway.
Two pyramids are visible through the doorway.
The sky, as seen through the doorway, contains a few clouds.

desc.objtitle:
Joseph and Potiphar's Wife,
full view including mount inscriptions

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the card-like paper on which the inscriptions are written. The tops of some letters of the inscription above the design have been trimmed off. The top inscription incorrectly identifies the female figure in the foreground on the right, holding a cloth in her raised left hand, as Jezebel.

desc.objtitle:
Joseph and Potiphar's Wife,
top mount inscription

objnote.p: The title inscription on the mount (the backing mat) above the design is not by Blake. It could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the card-like paper on which the inscription is written. The tops of some letters of the inscription have been trimmed off. The inscription incorrectly identifies the female figure in the foreground on the right, holding a cloth in her raised left hand, as Jezebel.

desc.objtitle:
Joseph and Potiphar's Wife,
bottom mount inscriptions

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) below the design are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the card-like paper on which the inscriptions are written. The inscriptions probably continued below the present lower margin of the mount before it was trimmed.

lg.l: And she spake unto her lord according to these words,
saying, the Hebrew servant which thou hast brought unto
